EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

I. INTRODUCTION
The regulations governing the Risk Management Plan were compiled to help prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, flammable or explosive chemicals.

The chemical used by Suisun-Solano Water Authority (SSWA) which is regulated by this standard is Sodium Hypochlorite(SH).  Sodium Hypochlorite is stored at the Cement Hill Water Treatment Plant and is used for the treatment of public drinking water for the city of Suisun.

It is the intent of the SSWA to comply with the regulations pertaining to management of acutely hazardous materials.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle SH, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the safe handling procedures that we use, and the training of our personnel.

4. First-aid measures
Inhalation Move to fresh air. Call a physician if symptoms develop or persist.
Take off immediately all contaminated clothing. Rinse skin with water/shower. Call a physician or
poison control center immediately. Chemical burns must be treated by a physician. Wash
contaminated clothing before reuse.
Skin contact
Immediately flush eyes with plenty of water for at least 15 minutes. Remove contact lenses, if
present and easy to do. Continue rinsing. Call a physician or poison control center immediately.
Eye contact
Call a physician or poison control center immediately. Rinse mouth. Do not induce vomiting. If
vomiting occurs, keep head low so that stomach content doesn't get into the lungs.
Ingestion
Burning pain and severe corrosive skin damage. Causes serious eye damage. Symptoms may
include stinging, tearing, redness, swelling, and blurred vision. Permanent eye damage including
blindness could result.

6. Accidental release measures
Keep unnecessary personnel away. Keep people away from and upwind of spill/leak. Wear
appropriate protective equipment and clothing during clean-up. Do not breathe mist or vapor. Do
not touch damaged containers or spilled material unless wearing appropriate protective clothing.
Ensure adequate ventilation. Local authorities should be advised if significant spillages cannot be
contained. For personal protection, see section 8 of the SDS.
Personal precautions,
protective equipment and
emergency procedures
Large Spills: Stop the flow of material, if this is without risk. Use water spray to reduce vapors or
divert vapor cloud drift. Dike the spilled material, where this is possible. Cover with plastic sheet to
prevent spreading. Absorb spillage to prevent material damage. Use a non-combustible material
like vermiculite, sand or earth to soak up the product and place into a container for later disposal.
Prevent entry into waterways, sewer, basements or confined areas. Following product recovery,
flush area with water.
Small Spills: Wipe up with absorbent material (e.g. cloth, fleece). Clean surface thoroughly to
remove residual contamination.
Never return spills to original containers for re-use. For waste disposal

, see section 13 of the SDS.

containment and cleaning up

C. Hazard Review
Based on a review of all operating procedures, as outlined in the Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP).  SSWA has concluded that SH leaks are the hazard involved in the chlorination process.  The following addresses the hazards of the chlorination process, the engineering and administrative controls applicable to Sodium Hypochlorite leaks and their relationships, consequences of failure of those controls, and the consequences of the effects on all workplace employees in or near the process area.
1. Chemical Release
a) Continuous Release:
SH can be released from a point source over a period.  An example of such a release is a leak through a line break or injection point connection.  Such a leak will get worse until the condition is corrected but the pumping system will alarm with no flow scenario and alert operations. I n addition secondary containment will collect all capacity of tank volume is scenario of a leak after pumping system,
2. Hazards to Health
a) General
Sodium Hypochlorite is primarily a skin & eye irritant.
b) Acute Toxicity
Liquid chlorine in contact with the eyes or skin will cause local irritation and/or burns.  All symptoms and signs result directly or indirectly from its direct irritation action.  There are no known systemic effects.
1) Vegetation:
Liquid Chlorine causes bleach spots on leafy plants due to attack on chlorophyll in the leaf.  Mature leaves are most susceptible to chlorine injury.  Usually the plant itself is not destroyed although yield or growth rate may be retarded.

als:

3. Administrative Controls:
a) All employees will be properly trained in accordance with the training outlined in this document.  The training is cross-referenced with SSWA's IIPP.  The training outlines leak control procedures as well as emergency measures in the event of a leak.
b) All employees who perform work operations around the chlorine storage areas, including but not limited to taking delivery storage containers, will be equipped with and trained to use the proper protective equipment.
D. Operating Procedures
1. Taking delivery of Sodium hypochlorite form DELIVERY TRUCK
1) One operator will be present, in addition to delivery person, to work on all loading and unloading of Sodium Hypochlorite.
2) Make sure you have available all necessary PPE.
3) Collect bill of lading and ensure correct chemical is being delivered.
4) Help delivery person connect hose to delivery pipeline and supervise entire delivery periodically.
2. LEAKS -MINOR AND MAJOR
1) If major leak occurs, refer to Emergency Response Procedures.
2) If minor leak occurs, notify support and supervising personnel and secure leak.
E. Training
Safe handling of SH depends upon the effectiveness of employee training, proper safety instructions, intelligent supervision, and the use of suitable equipment.  It is the responsibility of supervisors to train employees how to use personal protective and other safety equipment.  It is the responsibility of employees to properly use the equipment provided.  Training classes will be conducted to maintain a high degree of competence in handling procedures.  Employees will be informed of the hazards that may result from improper handling of chlorine.  They will be trained to prevent leaks and instructed regarding proper a

ction to take in case leaks occur.  Each employee will know what to do in an emergency and will be informed as to first aid measures.
Each employee whose primary duties include the operating or maintenance of a process and each employee before working in a newly assigned process shall be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures.  Training will coincide with training currently being conducted under the Employee IIPP Program.
Every year or if processes change, each employee involved as listed above will undergo refresher training.
Each employee undergoing training as listed above will be required to sign documentation that they have completed the above training.  The training documents will be kept with the IIPP training documents.
F. Mechanical Integrity
In the event employees realize potentially faulty or unsafe equipment, during routine inspections or daily operations, they are required to document the potential problem in writing.  The IIPP contains forms for such reporting.  SID will respond within 72 hours to the employee regarding the disposition of the employees concerns.
All chlorinators and regulators will be cleaned and inspected annually in accordance with SSWA "Cement Hill Treatment Plant Operations Plan".
Any deficiencies noted during the inspection process will be corrected in a timely manner.
Any modified, repaired, or fabricated equipment will meet design specifications and applicable codes existing at the time of manufacture.  Applicable codes include the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Petroleum Institute, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the American National Standards Institute, the American Society of Testing and Materials, the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors and the National Fire Protection Association.
G. Management of Change
In the event of a change in the process, for the exception of the replacement of parts or equipment in kind, the following will occur

:

1. The technical basis for the proposed change will be reviewed and approved by the appropriate individuals; in this case the Superintendent and Supervisor.
2. The impact of the change of health and safety will be given to affected employees for review.
3. The affected employees will be informed regarding the modification of operating procedures, if any.
4. All affected employees will be notified regarding the necessary time period for the change or modification.
5. Employees involved in the process being modified will be informed of and trained in, the change in the process prior to the start up of the modified process.
6. In the event the modification results in a change to the process safety information, that information will be updated immediately.
7. In the event the modification results in a change to the operating procedures, that information will be updated immediately.
H. Incident Investigation
In the event of an occurrence, the following procedures will be completed:
1. An investigation into the incident will be initiated by the Safety Officer / Risk Manager no later than 48 hours following the incident.
2. The investigation will be conducted by a team of individuals knowledgeable in the process involved in the incident.
3. The Safety Officer / Risk Manager will submit a written report to the superintendent with the following information:
a) Date of incident.
b) Date the investigation began.
c) Description of the incident.
d) The factors contributing to the incident.
e) Any recommendations for change resulting from the investigation.
4. The incident report will be reviewed with all operating and maintenance personnel whose work assignments are within the area where the incident occurred.
5. SSWA will promptly address and resolve the report findings and recommendations made by the incident investigation team.  SSWA will implement the report recommendations or take action to prevent the reoccurrence as soon as possible.
I. Compliance Audits
Every three ye

ars the Safety Officer / Risk Manager, Superintendent and Water Treatment and Water Quality Supervisor, will review and verify that the procedures and practices developed and detailed under this RMP continue to be adequate and are being followed.  Documentation of deficiencies and corrections will be retained at the Offices of the Solano Irrigation District.
J. Pre-start up Review
The Water Treatment and Water Quality Supervisor shall perform a pre-start up safety review for any new or modified stationary sources or equipment used in the chlorination process when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.
The pre-start up safety review shall confirm that new construction or equipment is in accordance with design specifications.  Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate.  Training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed. 
K. Employee Participation Plan
The Superintendent and/or Supervisor shall consult with employees and their representatives on the development and implementation of all process safety as it relates to any RMP regulated substances.  In particular, employees will participate in process hazard analysis and be consulted as to how the other elements of the prevention program are carried out.  At a minimum, total process review will be done and documented with all employees annually.
L. Hot work Permits   
Hot work refers to spark or flame producing operations such as welding, brazing, metal cutting, grinding, sand blasting, etc.  The Supervisor will issue a hot work permit describing the hazards of the work to be done and the needed precautions to prevent fires.  The permit shall also indicate the date authorized for the work to be done and identify the object on which the hot work will be performed.  The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.   
IV. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  
M. Sodium Hypochlorite L

eaks
As soon as there is any indication of the presence of liquid chlorine leak, immediate steps will be taken to correct the conditions.
Liquid chlorine leaks always get worse if they are not promptly corrected.  When a liquid chlorine leak occurs, authorized, trained personnel equipped with suitable PPE, will investigate and take action. If the leak is of a serious nature, the SSWA "Emergency Response Plan" will be initiated.  
When calling for assistance the following information should be provided:
1) Company name, address, telephone number, and the person to contact for further information.
2) Description of the emergency.
3) Travel directions to the site.
4) Type of chemical and of container involved.
5) Corrective measures being applied.
6) Other pertinent information regarding the weather conditions, injuries etc.
If the leak is serious the local Authorities must be notified to effect any necessary evacuation.  All personnel at the Cement Hill Treatment Plant who are involved in the handling of liquid chlorine or could be involved in an emergency will be trained in emergency procedures as out lined in training section of this document.

D. If an individual is overcome or burned by chlorine, the following steps shall be immediately taken:
1) Immediately remove individual from the contaminated area.
2) Call 911 for medical assistance.
3) If breathing is impaired, start CPR and do not stop until proper authorities arrive and take over first aid.
4) Eyes: utilize HAWs equipment.  Hold eyelids apart and flush for approximately fifteen minutes.  Seek medical attention.
5) Skin: Remove exposed individual and place under HAWs shower.  Remove contaminated clothing while shower is running.  Do not attempt to neutralize chlorine burns with chemicals, salves, ointments or soap.  Seek medical attention.
6) Inhalation: If individual is breathing, place victim in a comfortable position and keep still and at rest until medical attention arrives.
V. HAZARD ASSESSMENT
A. Five Year Accident History/ Reporting
As of the date of this plan, no accidental releases of chlorine have occurred resulting in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
B. External Event Analysis
The external event reviewed due to its high probability of occurrence was an earthquake event.  The analysis methodology selected is the "What-if" analysis.
In the event that an earthquake with a significant level of magnitude were to occur at the Cement Hill Water Treatment Plant what types of failure may take place in relation to the chlorination equipment operation and spill containment processes?  
If earthquake causes a line break or a storage tank leak the secondary containment has been specified with the volume required to safely hold all liquid.
What if an earthquake induced power outage was to occur?
All ancillary emergency electrical equipment for the containment vessels (leak detectors, shut-off valves, alarms) are powered during
electrical outages with on-site diesel powered electric generators.  If for some reason these generators do not respond as designed all SH delivery will be automatically stopped.
